name: Cheryl
comment info:
Immediately, an observable factor of the graph is that humanity, being the most specific group, is placed outside the other boxes, where the proportion of humanity to any other box is absolutely diminutive. The classifications are also evident, with technomass and biomass being separated. Nonetheless, viruses also are kept nearly isolated, with it not being considered a living organism but not being a man-made entity. What I wonder is that, unlike humans, the virus is kept closer to the biomass side of the spectrum for a reason that I cannot understand. It is neither man made nor technology, so it should reside in between the two classifications. Regardless, humanity is apparently put in the middle even though they are living organisms, and viruses are visualized in the domain of life. On the contrary, the graph can illustrate a perceivable contrast between humanity and their creations, disclosing that the human community is outnumbered by their resources, and showing the advanced state of human technology. Currently, humans are swamped by substantial issues such as climate change and warfare, which can easily be explained by the amount of resources available for humans to commence such harrowing actions.

name: Victoria AOSE

Headline: Man-Made vs. Living Stuff: What Makes Up Our Planet?
    This graph has different cubes representing the mass of multiple “living stuff” and “man-made stuff.” I think the purpose of this graph is to get readers to analyze and compare the different cubes. I also noticed that humans and viruses are the most miniature cubes, meaning they make up the least mass on the Earth. I also saw most of the cubes separated into two groups. The human cube is in between the two groups. I wonder why humans do not belong to the residing group. I also wonder what aggregates and asphalt are. We are a part of the human cube. In my community, we also witness the masses of other cubes. For example, we see plants, plastic, animals, metals, and bricks daily. This graph gives my community and me more awareness of our surroundings and the mass of different elements in the area.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graph is about the amount of biomass (natural) and technomass (man-made or nonnatural) on earth now.  
    
    From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online for the four questions.  If you include a claim, please back it up with evidence that supports your claim.  By Friday morning, we’ll give shout outs for some of the catchiest headlines and more.  There is no accompanying article, just the graph from the print version of the New York Times.
    
    You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  
    
    The next graph will be released by Friday, March 28.  The topic will be global wealth and unhappiness.

name: Addison AOSE
comment info: In this graph, I noticed that man-made mass is much larger than biomass on the Earth. In the biomass category, plants take up the most mass. In the man-made mass category, concrete takes up the most mass. I also noticed that humans were the smallest in comparison to every other recorded mass. I find it very interesting that while humans are such a small percentage of our mass, we impact the world so much. For example, all the man-made mass was created by humans and is the largest part of our earthly mass. I am curious what would happen if the biomass categories were equal or larger than the man-mad mass. I also wonder what would happen if the man-made mass was smaller, and was there a period where it was smaller? Finally, I am curious if, in the next 10 years, this graph will change and man-made mass might become even larger. This relates a lot to my community because humans are constantly creating and changing the world around us. Knowing the components of our Earth and how they impact it is extremely important to taking care of the world.

replies.comment info: @Addison AOSE My Title: Man-Made Mass: Making Up Our World

name: Owen
comment info:
What I noticed...
    The graph shows Earth's biomass versus technomass. Plants dominate biomass, followed by bacteria, fungi, and tiny animals. Viruses are smallest. For technomass, aggregates and concrete lead, with bricks, asphalt, metals, and small plastics following. Humans appear as a minuscule dot, yet our created materials now outweigh all living things.
    What do you wonder...
    I wonder how fast technomass is growing versus biomass. When did this crossover happen? Do certain materials cause more environmental harm despite smaller mass? How have human activities changed biomass proportions over time, and what might future trends show?
    How does this relate to you and your community...
    On Cape Cod, this graph reflects our delicate balance between nature and development. Our marshes, beaches and forests represent vital biomass, while vacation homes and roads add to technomass. Rising seas threaten both, making our community especially vulnerable. Our local conservation efforts directly impact this global balance.
    Catchy headline for graph...
    "Outweighed: How Human Made 'Stuff' Now Tips the Scale Against All Life on Earth"

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
Observations - This graph, in cubes, shows Earth’s biomass (left) and technomass (right). In terms of biomass, plants have the highest mass. Bacteria has the second highest, followed by fungi, archaea, protists, and animals. Next to viruses, humans have the lowest mass. Meanwhile, in terms of technomass, concrete has the highest amount followed by aggregates, bricks, and asphalt. Behind metals is plastic, which has the lowest amount. Comparing both sides, there is more technomass than biomass. 
    
    Questions - What factors have contributed to technomass surpassing biomass over time? How does the rise in technomass impact ecosystems and biodiversity? What are the environmental consequences of materials like concrete, bricks, and asphalt dominating Earth's mass?
    
    Relation to Community -  Acknowledging the growing amounts of technomass in NJ and understanding its trends would be instrumental in promoting more biologically-friendly actions to reduce the strain on the environment. 
    
    Headline - "Heavier Than Life: How Human Creations Tipped the Balance"

name: Layla Nelson
comment info:
A significant detail I noticed is that there is almost as much man-made brick mass as there is bacteria mass. I think that is very interesting considering how much brick there is and how large it is compared to usually invisible bacteria. I was surprised simply by how much bacteria mass there is on Earth. I also notice how little human mass there is. It is shocking to see how much man-made material there is compared to how many humans there are. 
    
    I wonder how this graph would look if mass of other man-made materials were included like cloth, glass, paper, etc. Additionally I wonder what the comparison would look like between the rest of the matter on earth (naturally occurring rocks and land). I wonder this because while we are seeing the comparison of natural mass and man-made mass, most of the man-made mass is created from natural resources that are not included in the visual representation. Lastly, I wonder what this graph would look like compared to the mass of the bodies of water on Earth.
    
    This relates to my community because I can see this comparison around me. The general mass of natural resources is currently depleting due to weather events and human activities. With global warming, it is alarming to see that there is already more technomass than there is biomass.

name: Leah Opdycke
comment info:
At first glance, I notice that plants have the largest biomass and concrete has the largest man made mass. I also see that viruses have a larger biomass than humans, which is surprising. Humans have the smallest total mass out of all the categories. Another surprising thing I notice is that there’s more plastic than animals on Earth.
    I really wonder why there are more viruses than humans because that doesn’t really make sense to me. I wonder why there’s so much concrete— almost enough to rival the biomass of plants. My biggest question is how protists, archaea, and bacteria could possibly weigh more than humans. They’re literally microscopic, so that must mean there’s an enormous amount of them on Earth. 
    This relates to me and my community because my generation will keep producing these man made materials until they weigh more than most of the bio forms.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Leah Opdycke --
    
    You are so right about many of these comparisons.  
    
    Be careful.  This graph shows masses and not number.  
    
    You got that it is unusual, for example, to compare the mass of concrete to the mass of bacteria.  There must be a LOT of bacteria since each one has so little mass.  I envision a balance scale with a chunk of concrete and a kazillion bacteria on the other side.
